update.description:
This adds a command to record and playback ignition transport topics using ignition tools.

```
$ ign log record -v 4 --file test.tlog
$ ign log playback -v 4 --file test.tlog
```

This is the final PR split off pull request #252

content.raw:
We would isolate each handler so that each one is handling its own data. Doing that would create duplicate simultaneous playbacks.

It might be valuable to add an API for synchronizing playback handlers, but I think that's beyond the scope of our current objectives.
content.html:
We would isolate each handler so that each one is handling its own data. Doing that would create duplicate simultaneous playbacks.

It might be valuable to add an API for synchronizing playback handlers, but I think that's beyond the scope of our current objectives.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 8: Ignition tools `ign log` command

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 8: Ignition tools `ign log` command

content.raw:
I like that API better too. One more question: Is the playback operation thread safe? Imagine this scenario:

* I call `Start()` and get a handler. If I'm not wrong this function spawns a new thread and return.
* I call `Start()` again and get a second handler.

Now, there are two threads running playback operations concurrently. Is this problematic?
content.html:
I like that API better too. One more question: Is the playback operation thread safe? Imagine this scenario:

  • I call Start() and get a handler. If I'm not wrong this function spawns a new thread and return.
  • I call Start() again and get a second handler.

Now, there are two threads running playback operations concurrently. Is this problematic?

pull_request.title: Logging Part 8: Ignition tools `ign log` command

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 8: Ignition tools `ign log` command

content.raw:
That's a really really good point that I hadn't considered.

All the messages that are to be published are retrieved during `Start()`, so you're right: none of the additional topics that you add after `Start()` will get published.

This makes me think that the "right" way to do things is `Start()` should return a `PlaybackHandlePtr` object which only provides the functions `Stop()` and `WaitUntilFinished()`. Those member functions would be removed entirely from the `Playback` class.

It would involve a little bit of refactoring, but I don't think it would take long. It would make our API and implementation much more airtight.
content.html:
That's a really really good point that I hadn't considered.

All the messages that are to be published are retrieved during Start(), so you're right: none of the additional topics that you add after Start() will get published.

This makes me think that the "right" way to do things is Start() should return a PlaybackHandlePtr object which only provides the functions Stop() and WaitUntilFinished(). Those member functions would be removed entirely from the Playback class.

It would involve a little bit of refactoring, but I don't think it would take long. It would make our API and implementation much more airtight.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 8: Ignition tools `ign log` command

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 8: Ignition tools `ign log` command

content.raw: I like that approach, seems more uniform. This comment made me think about the interaction between `AddTopic()` and `Start()`. What happens if I call `AddTopic()` after `Start()`? I'm guessing the operation won't take effect until the next call to `Start()`. Should we return an error when `AddTopic()` is called and the playback has already started?
content.html: I like that approach, seems more uniform. This comment made me think about the interaction between AddTopic() and Start(). What happens if I call AddTopic() after Start()? I'm guessing the operation won't take effect until the next call to Start(). Should we return an error when AddTopic() is called and the playback has already started?

content.raw: Ah OK, thanks. Up to you, not a big deal now that there's a reason.
content.html: Ah OK, thanks. Up to you, not a big deal now that there's a reason.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 8: Ignition tools `ign log` command

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 8: Ignition tools `ign log` command

content.raw:
Basically, the default behavior of creating a `Playback` object and calling `Start()` was to play back everything in the log, since this seems like the most likely use case.

However, we want to be able to support the use case that someone only wants to play back a selection of topics instead of all of them. Therefore, we assume that by calling `Playback::AddTopic(~)`, the user is explicitly providing a list and/or pattern of topics that they want us to play back.

One way we could improve our approach here is to mark the time at which the last call to `AddTopic(~)` was made, and then make sure that the time between that last call and the beginning of our playback is at least the duration of `_waitAfterAdvertising`.

That would probably make for the most streamlined user experience.
content.html:
Basically, the default behavior of creating a Playback object and calling Start() was to play back everything in the log, since this seems like the most likely use case.

However, we want to be able to support the use case that someone only wants to play back a selection of topics instead of all of them. Therefore, we assume that by calling Playback::AddTopic(~), the user is explicitly providing a list and/or pattern of topics that they want us to play back.

One way we could improve our approach here is to mark the time at which the last call to AddTopic(~) was made, and then make sure that the time between that last call and the beginning of our playback is at least the duration of _waitAfterAdvertising.

That would probably make for the most streamlined user experience.

content.raw: I don't want to name it `_waitMs` or `_waitMS` because that would imply megaseconds instead of milliseconds. I understand that this is a violation of our style guide, but I think it's justified by the fact that changing the capitalization changes the meaning of the prefix.
content.html: I don't want to name it _waitMs or _waitMS because that would imply megaseconds instead of milliseconds. I understand that this is a violation of our style guide, but I think it's justified by the fact that changing the capitalization changes the meaning of the prefix.

content.raw:
I've noticed that we currently seem to be missing unit/integration tests for the `ign log` CLI (like how we have `UNIT_ign_TEST.cc` for the `ign topic/service` CLI).

We do have unit tests for the API that `ign log` uses. I don't know if we should consider that sufficient or not.
content.html:
I've noticed that we currently seem to be missing unit/integration tests for the ign log CLI (like how we have UNIT_ign_TEST.cc for the ign topic/service CLI).

We do have unit tests for the API that ign log uses. I don't know if we should consider that sufficient or not.

content.raw:
It seems that there are some redundant messages when trying a playback command with a wrong file:


```
#!c++

caguero@bb20:~/workspace/ign-transport/build$ ign log playback --file xxx.tlog Failed to open sqlite database
Failed to open sqlite3 database
Failed to open file [xxx.tlog]
Failed to open log file
Failed to open log file
Failed to open log file
```
